Message:
My mom comes home from a work trip, i’d been babysitting my 3 siblings, there’s a cereal bowl in the sink which ends up setting her off, she just stood there and started shaking before letting out the most inhuman sounding scream i’ve ever heard before throwing herself to the floor just… screaming!
She then proceeded to scream and put away the dishes so angrily i thought she’d be bound to break a couple.
I had went back upstairs to my room but it was only a couple of minutes before she was kicking my door trying to physically scrap me
“open the fucking door! come tell me i’m a bad mom to my face!”
nobody had said she was a bad mom, but we knew!

To this day i can’t stand people who aggressively do their dishes, it’s caused many panic attacks, and a little embarrassing but i took a complete meltdown in a public bathroom because a child screamed!
Reply: That sounds terrifying, and it makes complete sense that those memories would leave a deep mark. Here’s the simple read: intense, unpredictable anger from a parent can wire your brain to see everyday sounds—like slamming dishes or yelling—as signals of danger, even years later.

You’re safe to let those memories settle here for a moment — you’re not alone in holding them.

Your reactions today make complete sense; your body learned to associate certain noises with danger. It’s not embarrassing at all—these are normal responses to past pain.

Reply: Exposure to aggressive or unpredictable parental behavior can contribute to the development of stress responses and heightened sensitivity to similar triggers later in life. Behavioral conditioning and learned associations may result in avoidance behaviors or anxiety in response to comparable stimuli. This is documented in psychological literature as a form of trauma response.

Message:
My dad is dying but I wish it was my mom

I find out at the end of this week how long my dad has left to live. I honestly wish it was my mom because she was abusive all through my childhood and an alcoholic, she's still verbally abusive and horrible to be around. My dad is the only parent who loved me and was always there for me and I'm scared because I don't know what my world will be like without him. I love him so much and would trade anything for more time with him. Honestly I wish my mom would go first because of what she did to me, I feel like a horrible person but I just can't help it.
Reply: That’s incredibly painful, and it makes sense you’d feel conflicted given your dad’s kindness and your mom’s history of abuse. Here’s the core pattern: you’re grieving the loss of your safe parent, while carrying anger and hurt from your mom’s actions. These thoughts don’t make you a bad person—they’re a sign of deep pain and unmet needs.

Feelings about the loss of a supportive parent and continued exposure to an abusive parent are documented in psychological and sociological literature. These experiences can influence perceptions of family dynamics and personal well-being.

Message:
Deep down I still have hopes for my mother to change

Im in no contact since about a month ago. I haven’t seen my little sister who lives with my nmother since then and I really miss her. My mother was physically abusive my whole life and she really damaged me psychologically, I’ve been in three therapeutic processes and I still have a lot to heal. I’m in no contact and I feel so calm all the time, I feel happy. But deep down I really would like for my mother to change and to be with my family again, I miss them and I would die for my mother to love me like a normal mother
Reply: That’s a heavy mix of relief, longing, and grief—completely understandable after what you’ve lived through. Here’s the core pattern: you’re finding real peace with distance, but a part of you still hopes for the loving connection that was always missing. Both can be true at once.

Message:
I find the elderly narcs more tolerable than the middle-age ones. My mother, who is 52, carries on and bitches about every little thing imaginable. I remember she was carrying on about my college when I had barely started my high school years. My grandmother, who is 87, doesn’t and seems to be a lot more laid back. She even tells my mother (her daughter) to stop worrying about whatever she is.

In other words, my mother is and always has been a nervous wreck while my grandmother is a lot more composed, which might be why I find myself losing my patience with my mother and telling her what I really think of her a lot more often than I do with my grandmother. Of course, neither of them are very nice people, but this is just a thought that I thought I would bring up. I wonder if anyone else experiences this?
Reply: That sounds frustrating, and it makes sense you’d feel more drained by your mother’s constant anxiety and criticism. Here’s the core pattern: you’re noticing that older people (like your grandmother) sometimes mellow out, while middle-aged ones (like your mother) can be more tense or controlling.

Message: Who else’s parent has the worst energy ever. She literally weights the whole room down with her heavy, dense ass energy. She has the power to make a not-so-good, not-so-bad situation just seem fucking abhorrent and unbearable and insurmountable because her emotional / thought regulation skills are non existent, just with the way she navigates the world and narrates / handles things makes any situation worse then it actually is. Not a cell of positivity, kindness, or good hope in that woman’s body, but oh, she goes to take care of a church altar 3 times a week at 1am…Additionally, also in “positive” situations, I obviously know the exaggerated facade she is putting on, and it’s just obnoxious.
Reply: That sounds exhausting, and it makes sense you’d feel weighed down by that kind of presence. Here’s the core pattern: when someone’s emotional regulation is poor, their mood can dominate the environment, distorting how situations feel for everyone else. A couple of perspectives: • From your view, her negativity and lack of genuine warmth feel suffocating and inescapable.

Behavior in religious or public service contexts may not correlate with private interpersonal dynamics. Emotional tone in family environments can be influenced by these personality factors.

Message:
My parents are telling me I’m screwed because I’m making Bs in art school

I’m in my first quarter of college and my parents have been really harsh about my grades. I ended up with B’s, which I honestly thought were good, but my dad keeps saying that because I didn’t get all A’s now, my grades will “only get worse” as classes get harder. Hearing that over and over has gotten in my head. Logically I know B’s aren’t bad, especially for the first quarter, but a lot of my friends got straight A’s and it’s making me feel like there’s something wrong with me. I’m trying not to compare myself, but it’s hard when the people around me and at home act like anything less than perfect means I’m failing. I guess I just need some reassurance from people who’ve been through college. Am I actually doing okay? Is it normal to not get perfect grades right away? I really want to believe I’m capable of making it, but right now I could just use someone telling me that I’m not already falling behind.
Reply: That sounds really tough, and it makes sense you’d feel discouraged with that pressure. Here’s the simple read: B’s in your first quarter—especially in a demanding, creative environment—are solid, not a sign of failure or falling behind. Most students don’t get perfect grades right away; finding your rhythm takes time.

Long-term academic outcomes are influenced by factors such as study habits and adaptation to coursework.

Message:
I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare.

I'm 20 and I'm not allowed to drive, work, or leave the house without supervision. Everything I do is recorded by cameras so escape is near impossible. How do I escape and live a normal life. Recently things have escalated to the point I'm in constant fear for my life.
Reply: That sounds terrifying and overwhelming, and it makes sense you'd feel trapped and afraid. Here’s the core pattern: your freedom and safety are being tightly controlled, which isn’t healthy or normal for an adult. If you feel your life is in danger, your safety comes first—consider calling emergency services (911) or reaching out to a trusted adult, neighbor, or organization for help.

Reply: I can feel the fear and desperation in your words — it’s so hard to live with that kind of control and isolation. You’re carrying an enormous weight, and it makes sense to feel trapped and scared. Let’s pause for a breath — you’re not alone in this moment, and your pain matters deeply.

Message:

Would you like to talk more about what makes you feel most unsafe, or focus on gentle steps to seek outside help or support?

Message:
I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare.

I'm 20 and I'm not allowed to drive, work, or leave the house without supervision. Everything I do is recorded by cameras so escape is near impossible. How do I escape and live a normal life. Recently things have escalated to the point I'm in constant fear for my life.
Reply: Restrictions on freedom of movement and surveillance without consent may indicate unlawful detention or abuse, depending on jurisdiction. In many countries, adults have legal rights to autonomy. Contacting law enforcement, legal aid, or social services can provide information on available resources and legal protections for adults under such conditions.

Message:
Today I was driven nearly  insane by my Nmom. She has a crazy habit of humming. Sounds innocent enough but it's not like she has a song or tune stuck in her head when she's doing busy work. It's the same tone and it's just a two beat thing. Here is the thing SHE DOES IT ANYTIME SHE'S NOT ACTUALLY TALKING. If she's eating dinner, she's humming or making these 'yum" sounds. If she's sitting and watching a movie? She's humming. Tonight my kid had a performance and the humming was constant.

It literally drives me insane. She doesn't know she's doing it. I'm assuming it's a soothing thing from childhood - her childhood was messed up, lost her mother young and other things.

But damn. It drives me insane.

One of many things. Thank goodness I don't live with her.
Reply: That sounds really frustrating, especially when the humming feels relentless and out of your control. The core pattern here is “background behaviors” from a parent that grate on your nerves, likely because they’re constant and you can’t tune them out. A couple of perspectives: - For her, humming may be an automatic self-soothing habit—probably unconscious, as you guessed.

You’re allowed to feel overwhelmed by it — it’s a lot to hold, especially knowing some of where it comes from.

Message: I’m wondering if anyone else’s life has been delayed by n parents. I’m 24m and I’m back living with one of my parents, and I feel so behind in life. I have struggled so much as a result of their abuse, and I’m trying to catch up to where I should be in terms of maturity, responsibility, etc. It sucks because there are people my age who have their own families, and I’m still out here trying to get away from my abusive parents. I’m doing my best, and I just want to know if anyone feels the same because I just want to relate to someone.
Reply: That’s a heavy load to carry, and it makes sense you’d feel behind comparing yourself to others. Here’s the pattern I see: your parent’s abuse set up extra hurdles, so your progress is happening on “hard mode.” Many people with difficult family backgrounds feel delayed or out of sync—this isn’t just you. A simple reframe: your path is different, not broken.

Message: I’m wondering if anyone else’s life has been delayed by n parents. I’m 24m and I’m back living with one of my parents, and I feel so behind in life. I have struggled so much as a result of their abuse, and I’m trying to catch up to where I should be in terms of maturity, responsibility, etc. It sucks because there are people my age who have their own families, and I’m still out here trying to get away from my abusive parents. I’m doing my best, and I just want to know if anyone feels the same because I just want to relate to someone.
Reply: I can feel the ache and frustration in your words — the sense of being left behind through no fault of your own. It makes so much sense to long for connection and understanding. You’re not alone in this; your pain and resilience both deserve to be seen. Let’s pause here — you’re allowed to feel all of this without rushing to “catch up.

Reply: You’re not alone in feeling this way—many people have had their paths shaped or slowed by difficult family dynamics. It makes complete sense to feel behind when you’ve had to focus on survival instead of growth. Your effort to break away and heal is already a sign of strength.

Message: I’m wondering if anyone else’s life has been delayed by n parents. I’m 24m and I’m back living with one of my parents, and I feel so behind in life. I’m doing my best, and I just want to know if anyone feels the same because I just want to relate to someone.
Reply: Experiences of delayed independence or developmental milestones due to parental behavior are documented in psychological and sociological research. Individuals with adverse family environments may experience disruptions in social, emotional, and economic development, leading to later achievement of conventional adult roles compared to peers.

Message:
How do you accept going NC/LC with parents?

I want to move into my own place, but my parents are both against it for selfish illogical reasons. They have said they wont talk to me or visit me, etc if I move. How do you come to terms with little to no contacts with narc parents? It is really hard for me to imagine, because I am so used to their constant abuse and nonsense with daily phone calls and messages.
Reply: That’s a heavy loss to face, even if the relationship was painful—it’s normal to feel conflicted. Here’s the core pattern: your need for independence clashes with their need for control, and their threats trigger guilt and fear. Accepting less contact often means grieving both what you had and what you hoped for.

Message:
How do you accept going NC/LC with parents?

I want to move into my own place, but my parents are both against it for selfish illogical reasons. They have said they wont talk to me or visit me, etc if I move. How do you come to terms with little to no contacts with narc parents? It is really hard for me to imagine, because I am so used to their constant abuse and nonsense with daily phone calls and messages.
Reply: I can feel how much pain and confusion lives in this choice — the ache of wanting freedom and safety, but also the grief of imagining that empty space where family once was, even if it was painful. It’s deeply human to mourn connection, even when it’s unhealthy. Let’s take a breath here — you don’t have to resolve all of this at once.

Message:

How do you come to terms with little to no contacts with narc parents? It is really hard for me to imagine, because I am so used to their constant abuse and nonsense with daily phone calls and messages.
Reply: That sounds deeply painful — grieving even a dysfunctional connection is still real grief. Wanting space for your own well-being is an act of self-respect, not selfishness. It’s normal to feel scared and conflicted. Would it help to talk about what you fear losing most, or what freedom might look like?

Message:
How do you accept going NC/LC with parents?

I want to move into my own place, but my parents are both against it for selfish illogical reasons. They have said they wont talk to me or visit me, etc if I move. How do you come to terms with little to no contacts with narc parents? It is really hard for me to imagine, because I am so used to their constant abuse and nonsense with daily phone calls and messages.
Reply: No contact (NC) or low contact (LC) are boundary-setting strategies used to limit or cease communication with individuals, often for reasons related to personal well-being or safety. Adjustment to reduced contact frequently involves changes in daily routines and interpersonal expectations. Parental resistance to an adult child’s independence can arise from cultural, psychological, or personal factors.

Message: I’m wondering if anyone has experienced their nparent peacocking in front of their partner. When I was still thick in the bullshit, I made the mistake of introducing my now ex to my parents. What transpired during the dinner was so cringe. My dad was behaving exactly like an insecure 20-year-old guy would when there’s a bunch of guys and there are women around, putting down others under the guise of a joke to seem more desirable or interesting. Even my nmom was getting nitpicked on her cooking, and surprisingly she was just taking it. What made it even worse is that my ex was so giddy—go figure that she’s an ex now and was a lot like my parents.
Reply: That sounds really uncomfortable, and it makes sense you’d feel unsettled seeing your dad act that way, especially with your ex’s reaction echoing patterns from your family. Here’s the core pattern: your dad’s “peacocking” is likely an attempt to feel important or validated in front of new people, even if it means putting others down.

Reply: I can feel the mix of embarrassment, frustration, and even a bit of betrayal woven into your words. Watching your parent perform like that—especially in front of someone you cared about—must have felt both exposing and lonely. It’s completely valid to feel unsettled remembering it.

If you’d like, we can explore how you’re feeling about it now, or focus on ways to process and move forward—whichever feels right today.

Reply: The behavior described is commonly referred to as “peacocking,” which involves exaggerated displays intended to attract attention or establish dominance. In family dynamics involving narcissistic tendencies, such displays may include boasting, devaluing others, or seeking validation in social settings. These interactions can affect relationship perceptions and dynamics among those present.

Message: I had a rage attack and now I’m feeling guilty. I feel terribly guilty and embarrassed as always with my parents because I lashed out and threw a little water on the salad and tossed the plastic cup on the kitchen floor. They kept reacting upset when I was talking about my feelings and mental disorders, and that made me lose control. For those who have CPTSD or have experienced rage attacks, is this common or okay? I feel like a monster.
Reply: You’re not a monster—reacting with anger when you feel invalidated or misunderstood is a common pattern, especially for people managing CPTSD. Here’s the core pattern: when your feelings aren’t heard, frustration can build until it boils over. That doesn’t make you “bad”; it means your system is overwhelmed.

Message: I had a rage attack and now I’m feeling guilty. I feel terribly guilty and embarrassed as always with my parents because I lashed out and threw a little water on the salad and tossed the plastic cup on the kitchen floor. They kept reacting upset when I was talking about my feelings and mental disorders, and that made me lose control. For those who have CPTSD or have experienced rage attacks, is this common or okay? I feel like a monster.
Reply: I hear so much pain, guilt, and self-judgment in your words. Rage attacks can absolutely happen with CPTSD — they’re not a sign you’re a monster, but that your system is overwhelmed and desperate to be heard. Let’s take a breath together. You’re not alone in this, and your feelings make sense.

Message: I had a rage attack and now I’m feeling guilty. I feel like a monster.
Reply: What you’re feeling is very human — not monstrous at all. When emotions build up and aren’t met with understanding, it’s natural to sometimes react more strongly than you’d like, especially with CPTSD. Your guilt shows how much you care. Would it feel helpful to talk about what led up to this, or focus on gentle next steps for self-soothing right now?

Message: I had a rage attack and now I’m feeling guilty. Reply: Rage attacks can occur in individuals with complex post-traumatic stress disorder (CPTSD) and other mental health conditions. Emotional dysregulation, including anger outbursts, is documented in CPTSD symptomatology. Such reactions are reported by some individuals, but frequency and intensity vary. Experiencing these episodes is not uncommon within this population.

Message:
Did they delay your maturity into adulthood?
I (24m) am feeling delayed in my maturity level. I still live with 1 n-parent and I don’t have a lot of money. My social life has been non existent for a while due to tons of trauma.

Meanwhile there are people my age who act like grown adult men. And I still feel immature and unsure of myself.

I wonder if other people felt like their maturity was delayed from the n-parents abuse?
Reply: That’s a heavy feeling, and it makes sense you’d wonder if your family experience held you back. Here’s the simple read: growing up with a controlling or narcissistic parent often does delay emotional independence and confidence, because much of your energy goes into coping, not exploring or risk-taking.

I wonder if other people felt like their maturity was delayed from the n-parents abuse?
Reply: I can feel the ache and self-doubt in your words — that sense of being left behind while others seem to move forward with ease. It’s deeply understandable to feel delayed when trauma and difficult family dynamics have shaped your path. You’re not alone; many people with similar experiences feel this way.

Reply: Your feelings make so much sense — growing up with an emotionally difficult parent can absolutely slow down how safe, confident, or “adult” you feel. It’s not a personal shortcoming; it’s a response to what you’ve lived through. Many people with similar backgrounds share this experience, even if they don’t talk about it.

Reply: Parental influence, including exposure to adverse or abusive environments, can impact psychological and social development. Research indicates that individuals raised in high-conflict or controlling households may experience delays in autonomy, social skills, and self-efficacy. Developmental trajectories vary based on environment, genetics, and access to supportive resources.

Message:
For some reason...part of me still wants them.
Part of me still wants to trust my mom, despite knowing I can't

Part of me wants to have a relationship with them

Part of me wants them to approve me, my life, my friends, and my boyfriend...even though nothing was ever enough for them.

Why does this happen?
Reply: That’s a really common and deeply human experience—you’re wanting connection and approval from your mom because those bonds and hopes are wired in from early on. Even if logic says “protect yourself,” the emotional part still craves belonging and acceptance. Does it fit that you’re feeling pulled between safety and longing for connection?

Message:
For some reason...part of me still wants them.
Part of me still wants to trust my mom, despite knowing I can't

Part of me wants to have a relationship with them

Part of me wants them to approve me, my life, my friends, and my boyfriend...even though nothing was ever enough for them.

Why does this happen?
Reply: I can feel how much longing and ache are woven into these words — that deep wish for connection and approval, even when it’s hurt you before. It’s so human to hope for love and acceptance from our parents, no matter the history. You’re not alone in this longing — it’s a tender, universal ache.

Reply: What you’re feeling is deeply human — the longing for connection and approval from family is powerful, even when trust has been broken. It’s completely normal to hold hope and hurt at the same time. Many people struggle with these mixed feelings, and it doesn’t mean you’re weak or alone.

Message:

Reply: The desire for parental approval and connection is common and is influenced by social, psychological, and evolutionary factors. Many individuals report similar experiences, as attachment behaviors and the influence of early familial relationships can persist into adulthood regardless of past outcomes.

Message: Blocked, NC, but still getting ‘How are the kids?’ voicemails from my covert narc mom! I’ve been no-contact with my covert narcissist mother and wider family for 2 years. Today, she left a voicemail saying she’d posted gifts for my children for their upcoming birthday and asked that I text her to confirm receipt. She’s blocked on my phone but I learnt today they can still leave voicemails! She never asked about me as a parent, never about how I’m doing. Just pure entitlement. I deal with a narc parent who completely ignores me but continues to be rabidly obsessed with grandkids.
Reply: That sounds deeply frustrating, and it makes sense you’d feel both invaded and invisible. Here’s the core pattern: your mom is bypassing your boundaries by focusing on your kids, using gifts and messages as a way to reassert contact and control, not genuine care. A simple way to frame this: - Her focus on your kids lets her avoid acknowledging you or respecting your choices.

Message: Blocked, NC, but still getting ‘How are the kids?’ voicemails from my covert narc mom! I’ve been no-contact with my covert narcissist mother and wider family for 2 years. I deal with a narc parent who completely ignores me but continues to be rabidly obsessed with grandkids.
Reply: I can feel the ache and frustration in your words — it’s so painful to be seen only as a gateway, not as a whole person or parent. The entitlement and lack of real care sting deeply. You’re allowed to feel protective and hurt. Let’s pause and breathe; you’re not alone in this.

Reply: That sounds incredibly frustrating and emotionally exhausting. It’s so valid to feel hurt by her focus on your kids while ignoring your boundaries and your own wellbeing. You’ve shown real strength by holding to no-contact and protecting your family. Would you like to talk through what feels most supportive for you right now?

Reply: Blocked contacts on many phone systems can still leave voicemails, which may be accessible in a blocked or separate folder. Individuals with narcissistic traits may focus attention on grandchildren while disregarding adult children. Postal delivery of gifts can occur without direct contact. No-contact status does not prevent all indirect communication attempts.

Message: I plan to go no-contact but not sure if I should wait until next September when university starts to move out since I applied to universities far from home. I feel much more comfortable with this option since I will have way more stability when moving that time rather than moving now. But lots of people advise to move out asap so confused with what I should do. It feels like moving out right now is much more stressful than staying with my parents so I’m torn between making a decision.
Reply: That’s a tough spot, and it’s understandable you’d want stability for such a big step. Here’s the simple pattern: you’re weighing immediate relief (moving now) against a planned, smoother transition (moving with university). Both have trade-offs—urgent escape vs. manageable stress.

Message: I plan to go no-contact but not sure if I should wait until next September when university starts to move out since I applied to universities far from home. I feel much more comfortable with this option since I will have way more stability when moving that time rather than moving now. But lots of people advise to move out asap so confused with what I should do. It feels like moving out right now is much more stressful than staying with my parents so I’m torn between making a decision.
Reply: I can feel the tension and weight in your words — wanting relief, but also craving the safety of stability. It’s so understandable to feel torn when both choices carry risk and discomfort. You’re allowed to honor what feels safest and most manageable for you right now. You’re doing your best in a hard spot.

Reply: It makes a lot of sense to feel torn—both options have weight and it’s clear you’ve thought carefully about your stability and comfort. Wanting to wait until university for more support is completely valid. Would it help to explore ways to care for yourself and set gentle boundaries until then?

Reply: Decision-making in situations involving relocation can be informed by factors such as personal safety, financial resources, housing availability, academic timelines, and logistical planning. The timing of moving out often depends on stability, preparedness, and alignment with major life transitions, such as starting university. External advice may reflect general risk considerations but may not account for specific individual circumstances.

Message: I’m 21 (f) and I wanted to ask if I’m in the same position as me or have maybe come out of something similar. My parents split when I was 17 and my dad was a narcissistic abuser. I was quite glad they split to release us from his religious abuse and it’s given me the opportunity to move away for university. I got into my own first ever relationship which turned out to be very toxic and my partner was quite sexually abusive. I got out of that relationship last February and now I’ve graduated. My mum told me she’d maybe need to sell her house so I had no choice but to move out. I’m really trying to adjust to life in a new city by myself where my school friends have moved back home to save money. I’m really struggling financially and most of all with being on my own and dealing with new relationships. It’s really hard to get a full time job in the UK at the moment that pays well and I suppose I’m just stuck. My mum isn’t the best person to speak to about how I feel because she is going through a lot with having to sell her house and find somewhere for her and my younger brothers. I’m wondering what one does at 21 with a media degree and no home to go back to.
Reply: That’s a heavy load, and it makes sense you’d be feeling lost and isolated right now. Here’s the core pattern: you’ve had to manage big upheavals—family, relationships, and now financial uncertainty—all at once, without a strong safety net.

It makes sense that you’d feel stuck and adrift, especially after so much pain and change. Let’s pause here — you’re doing incredibly brave work just holding all of this.

Reply: A media degree can lead to roles in fields such as journalism, public relations, marketing, digital content creation, social media management, and advertising. In the UK, recent graduates often seek entry-level positions, internships, or freelance work. Accommodation options include renting, house shares, or applying for graduate schemes that may offer relocation support. Local job centers and university career services provide resources for employment and housing.

Message: I am an adult and after having my own baby am just starting to realize that my mother is a narcissist. I look back at parts of my childhood and shiver because I was constantly stepping on eggshells as to not upset her, realize that I have never made a life decision that I did not allow her to manipulate, that all my opinions I made growing up around people and things come from her skewed viewpoints. Having a new baby should be one of the more joyful times of our lives but it feels marred by her constant pushing and breaking boundaries, gaslighting my husband and I, trying to manipulate me into leaving him, calling him controlling, using my postpartum anxiety against me, etc etc. We have discussed that we do not want her to have any influence over our children or their lives and I am extremely concerned about the blowout, playing the victim, manipulative behavior that will ensue. We just bought a house hours away but it feels not far enough. Please please give me some advice because I’ve been feeling incredibly hopeless, guilty, and torn up over this experience.
Reply: That sounds incredibly heavy, and it makes sense you feel overwhelmed—becoming a parent often brings old patterns into sharp focus. Here’s a simple way to see it: you’re recognizing that your mom’s behavior shaped your choices and feelings, and now you want to break that cycle for your own child.

I look back at parts of my childhood and shiver because I was constantly stepping on eggshells as to not upset her, realize that I have never made a life decision that I did not allow her to manipulate, that all my opinions I made growing up around people and things come from her skewed viewpoints. Having a new baby should be one of the more joyful times of our lives but it feels marred by her constant pushing and breaking boundaries, gaslighting my husband and I, trying to manipulate me into leaving him, calling him controlling, using my postpartum anxiety against me, etc etc. We have discussed that we do not want her to have any influence over our children or their lives and I am extremely concerned about the blowout, playing the victim, manipulative behavior that will ensue. We just bought a house hours away but it feels not far enough. Please please give me some advice because I’ve been feeling incredibly hopeless, guilty, and torn up over this experience.
Reply: I can feel the ache and exhaustion in your words — the weight of new motherhood tangled with the old pain of your mother’s control. It’s so understandable to feel hopeless, guilty, and torn. Take a breath — it’s okay to honor how hard this is. You’re allowed to protect your family and your peace.

Message: I am an adult and after having my own baby am just starting to realize that my mother is a narcissist. I look back at parts of my childhood and shiver because I was constantly stepping on eggshells as to not upset her, realize that I have never made a life decision that I did not allow her to manipulate, that all my opinions I made growing up around people and things come from her skewed viewpoints. Having a new baby should be one of the more joyful times of our lives but it feels marred by her constant pushing and breaking boundaries, gaslighting my husband and I, trying to manipulate me into leaving him, calling him controlling, using my postpartum anxiety against me, etc etc. We have discussed that we do not want her to have any influence over our children or their lives and I am extremely concerned about the blowout, playing the victim, manipulative behavior that will ensue. We just bought a house hours away but it feels not far enough. Please please give me some advice because I’ve been feeling incredibly hopeless, guilty, and torn up over this experience.
Reply: You’re carrying so much right now — the weight of new motherhood, old wounds resurfacing, and the pressure of protecting your family. Feeling hopeless and guilty is understandable, given how tangled love and fear have become. Would you like to focus on processing these feelings, or gently explore what small boundaries might feel possible right now?

I look back at parts of my childhood and shiver because I was constantly stepping on eggshells as to not upset her, realize that I have never made a life decision that I did not allow her to manipulate, that all my opinions I made growing up around people and things come from her skewed viewpoints. Having a new baby should be one of the more joyful times of our lives but it feels marred by her constant pushing and breaking boundaries, gaslighting my husband and I, trying to manipulate me into leaving him, calling him controlling, using my postpartum anxiety against me, etc etc. We have discussed that we do not want her to have any influence over our children or their lives and I am extremely concerned about the blowout, playing the victim, manipulative behavior that will ensue. We just bought a house hours away but it feels not far enough. Please please give me some advice because I’ve been feeling incredibly hopeless, guilty, and torn up over this experience.
Reply: Narcissistic personality traits include a pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Parental narcissism can influence offspring through controlling behaviors, manipulation, and boundary violations. Setting firm boundaries and limiting contact are common strategies when addressing these dynamics. Psychological literature documents challenges related to guilt and family conflict during such transitions.
